review.title: Comparison-Based Choices
review.abstract: A broad range of on-line behaviors are mediated by interfaces in which people make choices among sets of options. A rich and growing line of work in the behavioral sciences indicate that human choices follow not only from the utility of alternatives, but also from the choice set in which alternatives are presented. In this work we study comparison-based choice functions, a simple but surprisingly rich class of functions capable of exhibiting so-called choice-set effects. Motivated by the challenge of predicting complex choices, we study the query complexity of these functions in a variety of settings. We consider settings that allow for active queries or passive observation of a stream of queries, and give analyses both at the granularity of individuals or populations that might exhibit heterogeneous choice behavior. Our main result is that any comparison-based choice function in one dimension can be inferred as efficiently as a basic maximum or minimum choice function across many query contexts, suggesting that choice-set effects need not entail any fundamental algorithmic barriers to inference. We also introduce a class of choice functions we call distance-comparison-based functions, and briefly discuss the analysis of such functions. The framework we outline provides intriguing connections between human choice behavior and a range of questions in the theory of sorting.

metadata.title: Comparison-Based Choices

sections.heading: 1 Introduction
sections.text: This question can be asked at the level of individuals or at the level of populations that contain heterogeneous but related rankings. Crucially, a user has a ranking of alternatives that are hidden from us, and by observing their choices, that the choices made in these online environments have a uniform structure: users are confronted with a number of options - a list of recommended books, search results, flight options or users they follow - and they choose one or more elements from the set. The ubiquity of this framework has led to an active line of research on the problem of learning, the ranking of functions [1]. There are many formulations in the literature, but the essence is to assume that a ranking stands above alternatives that are hidden from us, and by observing their choices we would like to introduce this ranking.

sections.heading: 2 Active query complexity
sections.text: We will first focus on active query algorithms based sequentially on the results of previous queries, and our goal is to develop algorithms that, after a small number of queries, can either use any k-set function to select the "th alternative of k for some ordering"; we will mark this function with qk. "Our results in this section show that for each fixed k-based operation and each fixed but unknown" [1, k} we can, in fact, learn the output of an efficient twophase algorithm that performs only O (n log n) queries (up to a reflection we will discuss below), but we also give a simple algorithm that performs recovery (until recovery).

sections.heading: 3 Population mixtures
sections.text: The results in the previous section assume that all queries have been evaluated from the same deterministic selection function to some degree of compromise, with f (S) consistently selecting the "th ordered alternative from each k-set S." In this section, we show that we can restore selection functions in a more general environment in which the position selected by f is drawn over possible positions independently of a distribution. This setting includes two generalizations of our active query results, all of which base their decisions on the same ordered embedding, but differ in which position an individual is repeatedly queried, and may have compromise effects for some queries, independently of each other. Second, it describes situations in which queries are processed by individuals who base all their decisions on the same ordered embedding, but differ in an order in which their selection functions are selected. We show that we can still restore selection functions in this setting using O (n log queries), almost.

sections.heading: 4 Passive query complexity
sections.text: We shift our attention to passive query algorithms, algorithms that make all their queries at once, without the sequential utility of previous responses. This framework is motivated by a common scenario of studying large sets of recorded choices of online marketplaces, ranking algorithms, and referral systems. Could we still restore the selection function made by sets of alternatives, but often the queries cannot be directed adaptively toward our goal of restoring selection functions. What if we simply had a large corpus of choices by an individual about random subsets? If so, how few queries we would need, we analyze a model for this process in which we are unable to select queries, but must passively observe them instead. We focus on the output of a single f; handling population mixes in a passive query model is an interesting open question.Model of passive selection streams. We analyze the process of picking and analyzing the subsequent process of picking and picking over time.

sections.heading: 5 Distance comparison
sections.text: The question of whether this type of function is surprisingly rich, with the ability to capture compromise effects in decisions along any one-dimensional boundary, cannot be answered. In this section, we shift our focus to restoring selection functions defined by another structural relationship, namely distance comparisons in a metric embedding. A selection function for k-sets is a distance comparison if the value f (S) can be calculated using comparison functions defined by another structural relationship, namely distance comparisons. A selection function for k-sets is a distance comparison, if the value f (S) can be calculated from comparisons.

sections.heading: 6 Discussion
sections.text: The prevalence of choice-set effects in human decision-making underlines the need for a principled conclusion that can support the learning of such effects. In this work, we have proposed a framework that aims to support such integration by moving on a comparative level. We begin by mentioning a very concrete problem in the theory of sorting, including passive sorting ("sorting in a round") and sorting with distributed information. We begin by mentioning passive issues and population misunderstandings, without trying to combine these two aspects to derive a mixed collection of election functions.

Notable examples of such choice-set effects include the compromise effect, similarity aversion, and the decoy effect (also known as asymmetric dominance), and have been observed in diverse contexts both offline and online; recent work in machine learning has highlighted the prevalence of choice-set effects [23, 4, 33, 19] and non-transitive comparisons [7, 8], particularly in online search, online ads, and online games.

Notable examples of such choice-set effects include the compromise effect, similarity aversion, and the decoy effect (also known as asymmetric dominance), and have been observed in diverse contexts both offline and online; recent work in machine learning has highlighted the prevalence of choice-set effects [23, 4, 33, 19] and non-transitive comparisons [7, 8], particularly in online search, online ads, and online games.

A canonical example of a choice-set effect is the so-called compromise effect [24]: faced with the choice between a mediocre option for $10, a good option for $15, and an excellent option for $20, people will tend to choose the good option for $15; but faced instead with a choice between the same good option for $15, the excellent option for $20, and an outstanding option for $25, people will be more likely to choose the excellent option for $20.

By a theorem of Alon and Azar [2], it follows that if we compare the pairs of elements (ui, uj) defined by the edges of G, then with probability at least 1− δ1 we will be able to infer the relative order of at least a 1− γ fraction of pairs of elements of U ′, where γ and δ1 depend on b.

Distance comparisons form the basis of an additional important family of choice scenarios, namely choice queries answered with the “most medial” or the “most distinctive” alternative in a set, and in particular they model an important choice-set effect called similarity aversion [28]: given a choice between two dissimilar alternatives A and B and one of two alternatives A′ and B′ that are similar to A and B respectively, similarity aversion arises when f({A,B,B′}) = A but f({A,B,A′}) = B.
Observe that this question amounts to solving a version of the Fermat-Weber problem [32] with a very restricted functional toolkit, and may be quite difficult.

Beyond providing a model for similarity avoidance in the behavioral sciences, the ability to recover distance-comparison-based choice functions also speaks to a broad literature on learning metric embeddings of data from distance-comparison-based queries [20].

In that literature, the stochastic triplet embedding technique [30] has recently been introduced as a way to embed a generic dataset of elements through answers to choices of the form “Is A more similar to B or to C?”.
As an extension of that work, the crowd median algorithm [13] tries to learn embeddings from triplet queries with the request
Our treatment of distance-comparison-based queries also speaks to a broad line or research in psychology on pair selection queries used to infer cognitive embeddings [26, 14, 27].

Lastly, very recent work has developed learning results for binary clustering (a simple form of embedding) using so-called triangle queries of the form “which of these birds belong to the same species?” [31], with possible relevance to learning from distancecomparison-based choices.

metadata.abstractText: A broad range of on-line behaviors are mediated by interfaces in which people make choices among sets of options. A rich and growing line of work in the behavioral sciences indicate that human choices follow not only from the utility of alternatives, but also from the choice set in which alternatives are presented. Motivated by the challenge of predicting complex choices, we study the query complexity of these functions in a variety of settings. We consider settings that allow for active queries or passive observation of a stream of queries, and give analyses both at the granularity of individuals or populations that might exhibit heterogeneous choice behavior. Our main result is that any comparison-based choice function in one dimension can be inferred as efficiently as a basic maximum or minimum choice function across many query contexts, suggesting that choice-set effects need not entail any fundamental algorithmic barriers to inference. We also introduce a class of choice functions we call distance-comparison-based functions, and briefly discuss the analysis of such functions. The framework we outline provides intriguing connections between human choice behavior and a range of questions in the theory of sorting.
